rules.title: Use official place names
rules.message: Check spelling and capitalisation against the official authority.

rules.title: AU place names: standard alphabet (no diacritics)
rules.message: Avoid diacritics and non-ASCII letters in Australian place names.

rules.title: Place names are not possessive
rules.message: Avoid possessive ’s in official Australian place names.

rules.title: Hyphens/apostrophes only if official
rules.message: Use hyphens/apostrophes only when they are part of the official name.

rules.title: Dual names use a spaced slash
rules.message: For dual names, put single spaces on both sides of the slash.

rules.title: Capitalise place/region names
rules.message: Capitalise proper place and region names.

rules.title: Capitalise road/street types in names
rules.message: Capitalise the thoroughfare type when it forms part of the name.

rules.title: Address abbreviations: no full stops
rules.message: Do not use full stops with shortened address forms.

rules.title: Common address types: approved list
rules.message: Prefer standard abbreviations for address types (Av, Cct, Cr, Ct, Dr, Esp, Gr, Hts, Hwy, Pde, Pl, Rd, St, Tce).

rules.title: Last line of AU address format
rules.message: Use ALL CAPS locality + state/territory code + 4-digit postcode; no punctuation.

rules.title: State/territory short forms: no full stops
rules.message: Do not add full stops to state/territory abbreviations.

rules.title: Short forms only in 4 situations
rules.message: Use shortened state/territory names only when adjectival, space-limited, avoiding repetition, or in addresses.

rules.title: Buildings/structures/public places: initial caps
rules.message: Capitalise proper names of buildings/structures/public places; keep generic/plurals lower case.

rules.title: Private property names: initial caps
rules.message: Capitalise names of private properties (e.g., stations, homesteads).

rules.title: No punctuation in address service lines
rules.message: Write ‘PO Box’ and ‘RMB’ without full stops in addresses.

rules.title: Slash spacing (generic check)
rules.message: Ensure a single space on both sides of ‘/’ where required.

rules.title: Generic plurals lower case after named features
rules.message: Keep plural generic terms in lower case when following named features.

rules.title: List states/territories consistently
rules.message: Order multiple jurisdictions consistently (e.g., alphabetical) suited to context.

rules.title: Prefer generic product terms
rules.message: Use a common, non‑proprietary word instead of a brand where possible.

rules.title: Capitalise proprietary names
rules.message: Use initial capitals for trade marks, brands and business names (except stylised brands).

rules.title: Capitalise proprietary drug names; lowercase generics
rules.message: Use capitals for proprietary drug/chemical names; lowercase for generic names.

rules.title: Preserve brand stylisation (mixed/lowercase)
rules.message: Write brands exactly as styled by the owner (casing/spacing).

rules.title: Don’t auto-capitalise lowercase brands at sentence start
rules.message: Keep a brand’s lowercase style even at the start of a sentence.

rules.title: Spell ‘trade mark’ as 2 words
rules.message: Use ‘trade mark’ as 2 words. Replace one-word or hyphenated forms.

rules.title: Avoid ® and ™ symbols
rules.message: Avoid using ® or ™ in running text unless absolutely required.

rules.title: Use brand name only for that brand
rules.message: If a term is a registered trade mark, use it only for that brand and capitalise it.

rules.title: Treat genericised former brands as common nouns
rules.message: Use lowercase for genericised terms (e.g. aspirin, elevator, dry ice, linoleum, trampoline).

rules.title: Lowercase ‘google’ when used as a verb
rules.message: Use lowercase ‘google’ when it functions as a verb.

rules.title: Don’t rely on dictionaries for trade mark status
rules.message: Dictionary treatment doesn’t determine legal status; verify separately.

rules.title: Reference Australian trade mark search
rules.message: When in doubt, verify status using Australian trade mark search.

rules.title: Capitalise “Australian Government” only when words occur together
rules.message: Use “Australian Government” (caps) only when the 2 words occur together; use lower-case “government” for generic mentions.

rules.title: Bench is lower case
rules.message: Use lower case for “bench” and “full bench”.

rules.title: Capitalise “the Budget” (proper noun), lower generic budget
rules.message: Use cap B for the federal “Budget”; lower case for generic budget terms and adjectival uses.

rules.title: Capitalise “the Cabinet”
rules.message: Always capitalise “the Cabinet”.

rules.title: Avoid “Commonwealth government” for Australian Government
rules.message: Use “Australian Government”, not “Commonwealth government” (unless referring to “Commonwealth of Australia” as a constitutional name).

rules.title: Capitalise “the Crown”
rules.message: Always capitalise “the Crown”.

rules.title: Departments/agencies: cap formal names only
rules.message: Cap only formal department/agency names; use lower case for generic “the department/agency/commission/authority”.

rules.title: Always capitalise “the Treasury”
rules.message: Use “the Treasury” with a capital T.

rules.title: Divisions/groups: cap formal unit names; lower generic
rules.message: Use caps for formal internal unit names; lower case for generic references like “the division” or “the group”.

rules.title: Capitalise “Federal” only in formal names
rules.message: Use “Federal” only when it is part of a formal name; otherwise use lower case “federal”.

rules.title: Capitalise “Federation” for 1901 event only
rules.message: Use cap F when referring to Australia’s Federation in 1901; otherwise follow term usage conventions.

rules.title: Government: cap only in formal names
rules.message: Capitalise “Government” only when part of a formal name (e.g., Victorian Government); otherwise lower case.

rules.title: Programs/treaties: cap full names; lower generic/abbrev generics
rules.message: Use caps for full names and specific abbreviations; lower case for generic references like “the initiative”.

rules.title: Heads of state/PM titles: cap current holders; lower generic/former
rules.message: Capitalise formal titles of current office holders; use lower case for generic mentions and previous incumbents.

rules.title: Legislation terms: cap Act/Ordinance/Regulation/Bill; lower generic
rules.message: Use initial caps for Act, Ordinance, Regulation, Bill and for any Act references; lower case for generic bills, regulations and ordinances.

rules.title: Ministers/Secretaries: cap titles; lower generic
rules.message: Cap official titles; use lower case for generic references to ministers and secretaries.

rules.title: Prepositions: “Minister for…”, “Secretary of…”
rules.message: Use “Minister for [Portfolio]” and “Secretary of the Department of …”.

rules.title: Principals/CEOs titles: cap formal; lower generic/plurals
rules.message: Cap titles like “Chief Justice”, “Attorney‑General”, “Premier of …”; lower case for generic plurals (e.g., attorneys‑general).

rules.title: States/territories: cap formal names; lower generic/plurals; NT special case
rules.message: Use caps for formal state/territory names; lower case for generic/plural; “the Territory” may be used for NT.

rules.title: Parliamentary terms: cap formal names/titles; lower generic
rules.message: Cap Parliament House, Parliamentary Library, chamber officers; lower “parliamentary procedures”, “member of parliament”, etc.

rules.title: Houses of parliament: cap chambers; lower “houses of parliament”
rules.message: Cap “the Senate”, “the House of Representatives”, and equivalents; use lower case for the generic phrase “houses of parliament”.

rules.title: Lower-case general medical terms
rules.message: Use lower case for diseases, viruses, diagnostic procedures, syndromes and anatomical parts unless they are proper nouns.

rules.title: Capitalise genus names
rules.message: Capitalise the genus when writing scientific names.

rules.title: Italicise organism names
rules.message: Scientific names of infectious organisms must be italicised.

rules.title: Species epithet is lower case (in italics)
rules.message: In italicised binomials, the species epithet must be lower case (e.g. *Streptococcus pneumoniae*).

rules.title: Genus is capitalised (in italics)
rules.message: In italicised binomials, capitalise the genus (e.g. *Streptococcus pneumoniae*).

rules.title: Acronym in caps after full term
rules.message: Write acronyms/initialisms in UPPER CASE in parentheses after the full term.

rules.title: Full term is lower case (unless proper/genus)
rules.message: Spell out the full term in lower case before the acronym unless it includes a proper name or a genus.

rules.title: Drug: generic lower case + brand in parentheses
rules.message: Use a lower‑case generic drug name, with any Brand in parentheses (e.g. paracetamol (Panadol)).

rules.title: Avoid brand names alone for drugs
rules.message: Prefer generic drug names to brands unless there is a specific need to mention the brand.

rules.title: Person‑first language
rules.message: Use person‑first language (e.g. 'people with asthma', not 'Asthma sufferers').

rules.title: Scientific name in parentheses, not 'or'
rules.message: If providing both common and scientific names, put the scientific name in parentheses, not linked with 'or'.

rules.title: Eponyms: non‑possessive forms (discoverers/describers)
rules.message: Use non‑possessive forms: 'Alzheimer disease', 'Down syndrome', 'Henle loop'.

rules.title: Eponyms: possessive forms (named for sufferers)
rules.message: Use possessive forms where named for sufferers: 'Lou Gehrig’s disease', 'Legionnaires’ disease'.

RuleSet: Nationalities, peoples and places outside Australia

rules.title: Prefer official country/place names
rules.message: Use current official names from DFAT/UN/ABS and be consistent with the chosen form.

rules.title: Capitalise country and state names
rules.message: Countries and their states/territories/provinces take initial capitals.

rules.title: Lowercase article ‘the’ before country names
rules.message: Don’t capitalise ‘the’ before country/place names unless starting a sentence.

rules.title: Use shortened country names only when clear
rules.message: Short forms are acceptable only when unambiguous to users.

rules.title: Use English forms for places (noted exceptions)
rules.message: Prefer established English names; retain official non‑English forms where required (e.g. Côte d’Ivoire, Eswatini).

rules.title: ‘the Hague’ takes lowercase article
rules.message: Use “the Hague” (lowercase ‘the’).

rules.title: Lowercase generic eponyms
rules.message: Lowercase generic eponyms: brussels sprout, venetian blind, french door.

rules.title: Capitalise recognised regions; lowercase generic compass areas
rules.message: Capitalise official regions (e.g. South‑East Asia); lowercase generic compass areas (e.g. southern Germany).

rules.title: Capitalise demonyms and peoples
rules.message: Nationalities, peoples and religions should be capitalised (e.g. Filipino, Emirati, Sámi, Jewish).

rules.title: Avoid outdated country names
rules.message: Replace deprecated names with current official names (e.g. Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eswatini, Côte d’Ivoire).

rules.title: Language names may differ from country names
rules.message: Verify language names; they may not derive from the country name (e.g. Farsi in Iran; Dari and Pashto in Afghanistan).

rules.title: Capitalise clans and language‑based modifiers
rules.message: Capitalise clans (e.g. Clan Campbell) and language terms when used as proper modifiers (e.g. Hokkien‑speaking).

rules.title: Lowercase generic climate terms
rules.message: Write generic climate/weather terms in lower case (e.g. ‘climate change’).

rules.title: Lowercase cloud types
rules.message: Use lower case for scientific cloud names (e.g. ‘cumulonimbus’).

rules.title: Capitalise formal phenomenon names
rules.message: Use Initial Caps for spelled-out phenomenon names (e.g. ‘Indian Ocean Dipole’).

rules.title: Acronyms for phenomena are ALL CAPS
rules.message: Write acronyms like IOD and SOI in full capitals.

rules.title: Cap event-type before named storms
rules.message: Capitalise ‘Cyclone/Tropical Cyclone/Severe Tropical Cyclone/Hurricane/Typhoon’ when part of the official name.

rules.title: Include “Cyclone” on first mention
rules.message: On first mention of a specific cyclone, include ‘Cyclone’ with the given name unless clearly established by surrounding text.

rules.title: No italics for phenomena terms
rules.message: Avoid italics for climate and weather terminology.

rules.title: Drought naming case
rules.message: Capitalise formal period names (e.g. Millennium drought); keep generic year/descriptor terms lower case.

rules.title: Fire naming case
rules.message: Capitalise adjectival/proper parts of fire names; keep ‘fire/bushfires’ lower case.

rules.title: Year Location event casing
rules.message: In ‘year Location event’ names, only the location is capitalised; the event word is lower case (e.g. ‘1974 Brisbane flood’).

rules.title: Write names exactly as the organisation does
rules.message: Match the organisation’s official spelling, capitals, punctuation and logograms; include all words and don’t add extras.

rules.title: Capitalise all‑lowercase brand names in body text
rules.message: If an official name is all lowercase, use an initial capital in running text so it reads as a proper noun.

rules.title: Preserve medial capitals even at sentence start
rules.message: Keep internal capitals (e.g. eBay) exactly as styled, including when the name begins a sentence.

rules.title: Don’t invent or misuse shortened forms
rules.message: Use a shortened form only if the organisation uses it; spell out the full name on first mention unless the name is known only by the shortened form.

rules.title: No full stops in Co/Inc
rules.message: Remove the full stop after ‘Co’ or ‘Inc’ unless it ends the sentence.

rules.title: No full stops in Pty/Ltd
rules.message: Don’t punctuate ‘Pty’ or ‘Ltd’ with a full stop.

rules.title: First mention uses full legal name
rules.message: Use the organisation’s full legal title on first mention in a publication.

rules.title: Follow preferred capitalisation (incl. ABR names)
rules.message: If ABR shows ALL CAPS, still follow the organisation’s preferred capitalisation from its site/publications.

rules.title: Lowercase generic references
rules.message: Use lower case for generic terms like ‘the department/agency/university/company/council/summit/academy/royal commission’ when not part of a full name.

rules.title: Lowercase ‘the’ in body text
rules.message: In running text, use lower‑case ‘the’ before organisation names even if ‘The’ is part of the official name (except in letters/emails and alphabetised lists).

rules.title: Apostrophes only if official
rules.message: Include a possessive apostrophe in an organisation’s name only when it forms part of the official name.

rules.title: Use singular verbs with organisation names
rules.message: Take a singular verb with organisation names, even if they look plural or end in ‘s’.

rules.title: Use the form of name the person uses
rules.message: Use the person’s preferred spelling, punctuation and capitalisation; consult reliable sources if unsure.

rules.title: Use APS-preferred terms for name parts
rules.message: Prefer ‘given name’, ‘family name’, and ‘previous names’.

rules.title: Ban “Christian name”
rules.message: Use ‘given name’ instead of ‘Christian name’.

rules.title: Prefer “family name” over “surname”
rules.message: Use ‘family name’ instead of ‘surname’.

rules.title: Prefer “previous names” over “maiden name”
rules.message: Use ‘previous names’ instead of ‘maiden name’.

rules.title: Capitalise names
rules.message: Capitalise names of real/fictitious people, except where individuals deliberately use lowercase.

rules.title: Initials: no full stops
rules.message: Remove full stops from initials (e.g., ‘A.D. Hope’ → ‘AD Hope’).

rules.title: Initials: unspaced between letters
rules.message: Join multiple initials with no spaces (e.g., ‘A D Hope’ → ‘AD Hope’).

rules.title: Nicknames quoted and capitalised on first mention
rules.message: Put nicknames in quotation marks and capitalise them on first mention.

rules.title: No apostrophes in plural family names
rules.message: Form plurals with s/es (e.g., ‘the Murphys’, ‘3 Alexes’), not ’s.

rules.title: Possessive singular takes ’s even after s
rules.message: For a single person’s name ending in s, use ’s (e.g., ‘Jas’s report’).

rules.title: Possessive plural of names: only apostrophe
rules.message: For plural family names, add only an apostrophe after -es (e.g., ‘Joneses’ → ‘Joneses’ car’).

rules.title: Retain hyphens in names
rules.message: Keep hyphens in hyphenated given or family names.

rules.title: Write all parts of compound family names
rules.message: Include all parts on first mention; then use the well-known family name.

rules.title: Respect case of particles; cap at sentence start
rules.message: Follow the person’s capitalisation; capitalise the particle when the name starts a sentence.

rules.title: Keep diacritics in names
rules.message: Retain diacritic marks unless the person uses a simplified form.

rules.title: Non-English names: follow person’s order/spelling
rules.message: Use the name order and spelling the person uses; be mindful of cultural conventions.

rules.title: Reference lists: family name first
rules.message: In reference lists, put family name first for lead author and use initials.

rules.title: Scientific binomials must be italicised
rules.message: Write genus + species in italics; genus capitalised, species lower case. Include italics markup in Markdown/HTML.

rules.title: Genus capital; species lower case (within italics)
rules.message: Within italicised binomials, flag capitalised species or lowercase genus.

rules.title: Don’t italicise ranks above genus
rules.message: Family/order/class names should be roman type with initial capitals, not italic.

rules.title: Family names start with a capital
rules.message: Capitalise zoological/botanical family names (‑idae/‑ceae).

rules.title: Subspecies/variety abbreviations take a full stop
rules.message: Use ‘subsp.’, ‘subspp.’, ‘var.’, ‘subvar.’, ‘f.’, ‘subf.’ with a full stop.

rules.title: Keep taxon abbreviations roman (not italic)
rules.message: Do not italicise the abbreviations; only the names are italic.

rules.title: Common names are lower case and not italic
rules.message: Use lower case roman for common names unless a proper noun or trade mark.

rules.title: Proper nouns in common names take capitals
rules.message: Capitalise embedded proper nouns in common names (e.g., ‘Norfolk Island pine’).

rules.title: Include scientific name at first mention
rules.message: At the first mention of a common name, include the genus and species in parentheses.

rules.title: Abbreviate repeated genus with a dot
rules.message: Use an initial + full stop for abbreviated genus (e.g., ‘O. anatinus’).

rules.title: Disambiguate genus abbreviations when needed
rules.message: When multiple genera share an initial, use two-letter abbreviations (e.g., ‘An.’, ‘Al.’).

rules.title: Prefer <em> over <i> for italics
rules.message: Use semantic … for italics in HTML for accessibility.

rules.title: Don’t italicise single common words by mistake
rules.message: Avoid italicising single lowercase common nouns (reserve italics for scientific names).

rules.title: Bird names lower case in generalist content
rules.message: Write bird common names in lower case unless a proper noun; lists of common names are lower case.

rules.title: Genes italic; proteins roman
rules.message: Italicise gene names; write proteins in roman with initial capital only.

rules.title: Use numerals for 2+ in running text
rules.message: In prose and headings, use numerals for 2 and above; write ‘zero’ and ‘one’ as words. Be consistent.

rules.title: Write ‘zero’ and ‘one’ (avoid 0/1)
rules.message: Avoid standalone digits 0 or 1 in prose; write ‘zero’ and ‘one’ unless technical context requires numerals.

rules.title: Don’t start a sentence with numerals
rules.message: Rewrite or spell out numbers that begin a sentence.

rules.title: Fractions in general text use words
rules.message: Write fractions as words in general text; use decimals when precision matters.

rules.title: Proper names/titles keep words-as-words
rules.message: Preserve number-as-word styling when it is part of a proper noun or publication title.

rules.title: Figures of speech use words
rules.message: Write numbers as words in idioms and figures of speech.

rules.title: Units of measurement use numerals
rules.message: Use a numeral with units of measurement (e.g. ‘1 km’, ‘5 kg’).

rules.title: Maths/ratios/decimals use numerals
rules.message: Show equations, ratios and decimals with numerals and proper operators/spaces (e.g. ‘7∶1’, ‘8 + 1 = 9’).

rules.title: Comparisons use like-with-like numerals
rules.message: Use numerals (decimal with decimal) for quantitative comparisons; avoid vague ‘twice’ unless clearer for users.

rules.title: Data displays use numerals
rules.message: In tables, graphs and charts, use numerals rather than words for values.

rules.title: Dates and times use numerals
rules.message: Write dates and times with numerals (e.g. ‘1 April 2020’, ‘1 pm’).

rules.title: Series/statistics use numerals
rules.message: When content contains many numbers or statistics, use numerals consistently.

rules.title: Steps and references use numerals
rules.message: Use numerals for steps/point references (e.g. ‘Step 3’, ‘point 2’).

rules.title: Ages and school years use numerals
rules.message: Use numerals for ages and school years (e.g. ‘12‑year‑olds’, ‘year 5’).

rules.title: Use commas in 4+ digit numbers
rules.message: Insert commas every three digits for numbers with 4+ digits (e.g. ‘2,500’).

rules.title: Ban spaced thousands
rules.message: Do not separate thousands with spaces or NBSP; use commas.

rules.title: Large rounded numbers: numeral + word
rules.message: Prefer compact ‘2.5 million’, ‘$50 billion’ over long digit strings when values are rounded.

rules.title: ‘1 million’ vs ‘one million’ (context)
rules.message: Use ‘1 million’ in technical/number‑heavy/comparison/currency contexts; ‘one million’ to start sentences or where numerals may be confused.

rules.title: Currency amounts use symbols
rules.message: Use currency symbols with numerals (e.g. ‘$1’, ‘US$20,000’); reserve words for approximations/idioms.

rules.title: No space between symbol and numerals
rules.message: Write currency symbol directly before numerals (no space): e.g., $27.99.

rules.title: Exactly 2 decimals for dollar cents
rules.message: Use exactly 2 decimal places for dollar amounts (e.g., $0.80).

rules.title: Leading zero for < $1 amounts
rules.message: Include a leading zero before the decimal for amounts under $1 (e.g., $0.04).

rules.title: Cents style: no space, no full stop
rules.message: Write cents as digits + 'c' without a space and without a full stop (unless end of sentence).

rules.title: Use $ for clearly-AUD contexts
rules.message: When context is clearly Australian, use $ (not A$).

rules.title: Use A$ when currency may be unclear
rules.message: Use A$ if there’s a chance readers could confuse the currency with another dollar currency.

rules.title: Prefer IBAN codes for foreign currency
rules.message: Prefer 3-letter IBAN currency codes (AUD, USD, THB, etc.) across all currencies for accessibility.

rules.title: IBAN code spacing
rules.message: Don’t put a space between the IBAN currency code and the numerals (e.g., AUD19.49).

rules.title: No symbol + IBAN together
rules.message: Don’t combine a currency symbol with a 3-letter currency code (e.g., $7.25 USD).

rules.title: Country-prefixed $: no space
rules.message: For US$/NZ$/A$/C$, don’t insert a space before the numerals (e.g., US$7.25).

rules.title: Explain unfamiliar symbols on first use
rules.message: If using a foreign currency symbol that’s not widely known, explain it on first mention.

rules.title: Avoid non-AUD symbols unless needed
rules.message: Avoid non-AUD currency symbols unless there’s a demonstrated user need.

rules.title: Former Australian currency in words
rules.message: Write former Australian currency as words: pounds, shillings and pence (avoid £, s, d).

rules.title: Match precision to context
rules.message: Use appropriate precision: descriptive (‘more than $2.1 million’), reports ($2.195 million), tables ($2.195m with a note).

rules.title: 'm' in tables: tight, no full stop
rules.message: In tables/charts write millions as $<amount>m with no space and no trailing full stop.

rules.title: Use words for inexact amounts
rules.message: For inexact monetary amounts, use words (e.g., ‘several million dollars’).

rules.title: Day–Month–Year in body text
rules.message: Use Australian sequence “d Month yyyy” without a comma (e.g., 31 December 2020).

rules.title: No ordinals in full dates
rules.message: Don’t use ordinal suffixes in dates with a month (write ‘1 May’, not ‘1st May’).

rules.title: US month–day–year banned
rules.message: Avoid US order ‘Month 1, 2024’; use ‘1 Month 2024’.

rules.title: No comma after weekday
rules.message: Don’t insert a comma after the weekday in dates (write ‘Wednesday 7 August 2024’).

rules.title: Numeric date uses slashes
rules.message: In general content, don’t use hyphens or full stops for dates; prefer slashes (d/m/yyyy).

rules.title: Two‑digit year discouraged
rules.message: Avoid 2‑digit years in dates unless context makes the century clear.

rules.title: No apostrophe in decades
rules.message: Write decades without an apostrophe (e.g., 1980s, not 1980’s).

rules.title: Year spans in words (general)
rules.message: Prefer ‘from 2015 to 2019’ or ‘between 2015 and 2019’ in body text (reserve en dashes for specified cases).

rules.title: En dash for specified year spans
rules.message: Use unspaced en dashes for financial/calendar years and in titles (e.g., 2021–22 financial year).

rules.title: Spans of days/months in words
rules.message: Write ‘from 3 to 21 December’ or ‘between 6 and 8 September’; use en dashes only when space is limited.

rules.title: Colon in times, not full stop
rules.message: Use a colon between hours and minutes (e.g., 9:45 am, not 9.45 am).

rules.title: Lowercase am/pm with space
rules.message: Write am/pm in lowercase with a (non‑breaking) space: ‘10 am’, ‘6:30 pm’. (Flags uppercase or missing space).

rules.title: No am/pm + morning/afternoon
rules.message: Don’t duplicate the time of day (‘10 am tomorrow morning’).

rules.title: Prefer noon/midday/midnight
rules.message: Use ‘midnight/noon/midday’ instead of ‘12 am/pm’.

rules.title: 24‑hour leading zero
rules.message: In 24‑hour format, include a leading zero for hours 0–9 (e.g., 05:30).

rules.title: No am/pm with 24‑hour time
rules.message: Omit am/pm when using 24‑hour time.

rules.title: Uppercase AU time zones
rules.message: Write Australian time‑zone initialisms in uppercase (e.g., AEDT).

rules.title: Spaced en dash with am/pm spans
rules.message: Add spaces around the en dash when am/pm appears on both sides (e.g., ‘7 am – 4 pm’).

rules.title: Unspaced en dash in 24‑hour spans
rules.message: Remove spaces around the en dash for 24‑hour spans (e.g., ‘08:00–08:15’).

rules.title: Don’t mix words with en dash
rules.message: Use words (‘from … to’, ‘between … and’) or an en dash—not both in the same span.

rules.title: No plural “s” on time units
rules.message: Use unit symbols without ‘s’: s, min, h, d, wk, mo, y/yr (e.g., ‘15 min’, not ‘15 mins’).

rules.title: Avoid ambiguous ‘bi‑’ terms
rules.message: Avoid bimonthly/biannual/biennial; state the exact frequency.

rules.title: ISO datetime (if used)
rules.message: When using ISO formats, prefer the extended form with ‘T’ (e.g., 2023-08-11T12:15:05).

rules.title: Leading zero before decimals <1
rules.message: For values less than one, include a leading 0 before the decimal point (e.g., 0.59).

rules.title: Decimal point is a full stop
rules.message: Use a full stop (.) for decimal points, not a comma.

rules.title: Fractions in running text are words
rules.message: Write simple fractions as words in running text (for example, two-thirds), not 2/3.

rules.title: Decimals are numerals
rules.message: Write decimal values as numerals in text (for example, 7.5).

rules.title: Use decimals for precision
rules.message: Prefer decimals when an exact/precise value is required.

rules.title: Use fractions for approximate values
rules.message: Prefer worded fractions when precision is not important and readers only need a general idea.

rules.title: Prefer words to symbols in general content
rules.message: Describe mathematical relationships in words unless user research supports symbols in this context.

rules.title: Use Unicode minus, not hyphen
rules.message: Use the true minus (−, U+2212) for subtraction and negative numbers, not hyphen-minus (-).

rules.title: No spaces around ratio colon
rules.message: Write ratios with no spaces around the colon: e.g. 5:1 or 5∶1.

rules.title: Addition spaced; positive sign unspaced
rules.message: Use spaces around + for operations (e.g. 2 + 10) and no space after + for positive values (+3).

rules.title: Subtraction spaced; negative sign unspaced
rules.message: Use spaces around − for subtraction (e.g. 12 − 4) and no space after − for negative values (−5).

rules.title: Use × for multiplication (not x, *, ⋅)
rules.message: Use × (U+00D7) for multiplication in prose; avoid letter x, asterisk, or dot operator.

rules.title: Space around ×
rules.message: Use spaces around × when used as an operator (e.g. 3 × 4).

rules.title: Division symbol spaced; avoid slash in prose
rules.message: Use spaces around ÷ in prose; prefer ∕ (unspaced) for mathematical notation; avoid plain '/' except in code contexts.

rules.title: Space around ÷
rules.message: Use spaces around ÷ (e.g. 8 ÷ 2).

rules.title: Space around relational symbols
rules.message: Add spaces around <, >, ≤, ≥ in comparisons (except compact range shorthand).

rules.title: Compact range shorthand (no space)
rules.message: When expressing a bound like <6.74 or >10, do not insert a space after the symbol.

rules.title: Don’t use >= or <=
rules.message: Use the single-character forms ≤ and ≥ in general content.

rules.title: Equations: space around equals
rules.message: Insert spaces around = in equations (e.g. x + 1 = 2).

rules.title: Numbers as numerals in maths expressions
rules.message: Write numbers as numerals in mathematical expressions (e.g. 0 does not equal 1).

rules.title: Use coded symbols, not punctuation/images
rules.message: Insert true symbol code points (Unicode/LaTeX/MathML); do not fake with punctuation or images.

rules.title: Use a non‑breaking space between number and unit
rules.message: Use a non-breaking space (U+00A0) between numerals and unit symbols.

rules.title: Don’t omit the space before unit
rules.message: Insert a space (prefer NBSP U+00A0) between the number and unit (avoid forms like 5kg).

rules.title: No full stop after unit symbols
rules.message: Do not add a full stop after unit symbols.

rules.title: No plural “s” on symbols
rules.message: Unit symbols do not take a plural “s” (write 56 km, not 56 kms).

rules.title: Use numerals with units (not words)
rules.message: Use numerals next to units (e.g., 5 t, not “five t”).

rules.title: Don’t mix words with symbols like “square km”
rules.message: Use the correct symbol (km², m³) instead of “square km” or “cubic m”.

rules.title: Prefer standard SI prefixes and symbols
rules.message: Use standard symbols (e.g., µg, mL) and avoid non‑standard forms like mcg or uncommon dL.

rules.title: Use ‘L’ for litre after numerals
rules.message: Prefer capital ‘L’ for litre in most government content (e.g., 1.5 L).

rules.title: Use km/h for speed
rules.message: Express speed as km/h (not kph or kmph).

rules.title: Avoid imperial units
rules.message: Avoid imperial units for AU content; if required, provide SI equivalents.

rules.title: Spell out common time units in running text
rules.message: Spell out hours, minutes and years in running text (tables/lists may abbreviate).

rules.title: Spell out 1st–9th
rules.message: Spell out ordinals from ‘first’ to ‘ninth’; use numerals from ‘10th’.

rules.title: Numerals for centuries
rules.message: Use ordinal numerals with centuries and keep ‘century’ lower case.

rules.title: No superscript ordinal suffixes
rules.message: Do not write ordinal suffixes in superscript.

rules.title: Suffix on ordinal numerals
rules.message: Add the correct ordinal suffix (st/nd/rd/th) when a numeral functions as an ordinal.

rules.title: Spell out very large rounded ordinals
rules.message: Spell out large rounded ordinals (for readability).

rules.title: Editions use numeral+suffix
rules.message: In references, use numerals with suffix for editions (e.g. ‘2nd edn’).

rules.title: Avoid ordinals for steps
rules.message: For instructions/sequences, prefer numbered lists instead of ‘first/second/third’ in prose.

rules.title: ‘Firstly/Secondly’ paired only
rules.message: If using ordinal adverbs in journals/reports, ensure ‘Firstly’ is paired with ‘Secondly’; otherwise avoid.

rules.title: Ban ‘thirdly’
rules.message: Do not use ‘thirdly’; recast as a simple list.

rules.title: No ordinals in dates
rules.message: Write dates without ordinal suffixes (e.g. ‘12 February 2020’).

rules.title: Regnal numbers are Roman numerals
rules.message: Use upper-case Roman numerals for regnal numbers (e.g. ‘Elizabeth I’).

rules.title: Non-breaking space before regnal numeral
rules.message: Use a non-breaking space (U+00A0) between name and regnal number.

rules.title: Lower case ‘century/centuries’
rules.message: Keep ‘century/centuries’ lower case (e.g. ‘9th century’).

rules.title: Numerals with % sign
rules.message: Write percentages with no space before the % sign.

rules.title: Use decimals not fractions
rules.message: Use decimals with % instead of fractions.

rules.title: Avoid sentence-starting %
rules.message: Do not start sentences with a numeral + %; reword or spell out.

rules.title: Correct noun form
rules.message: Use ‘percentage’ as the noun, not ‘per cent’.

rules.title: AU spelling ‘per cent’
rules.message: Use Australian spelling ‘per cent’, not ‘percent’.

rules.title: Avoid % for describing change
rules.message: Describe actual increase/decrease rather than a percentage change.

rules.title: Concise presentation of many %
rules.message: Use brackets or lists when citing multiple percentages.

rules.title: AU landline – national format
rules.message: Format Australian landlines as 0[2378] #### ####.

rules.title: AU mobile – national format
rules.message: Format Australian mobiles as 04## ### ###.

rules.title: 13 numbers
rules.message: Format 13 numbers as 13 ## ##.

rules.title: 1300 numbers
rules.message: Format 1300 numbers as 1300 ### ###.

rules.title: 1800 numbers
rules.message: Format 1800 numbers as 1800 ### ###.

rules.title: AU mobile – international format
rules.message: Use +61 4## ### ### (omit leading 0).

rules.title: No unchunked AU mobiles
rules.message: Add spaces: 04## ### ###.

rules.title: No unchunked +61 numbers
rules.message: Add spaces to +61 numbers per APS format.

rules.title: 'tel:' href – no spaces
rules.message: Remove spaces from tel: URIs in HTML.

rules.title: 'tel:' visible text uses no-break spaces
rules.message: In HTML, use   (or U+00A0) between chunks so numbers don’t wrap.

rules.title: Narrow no-break space for print
rules.message: Use U+202F between chunks in print/PDF to prevent wrapping and uneven spacing.

rules.title: No 'phone words'
rules.message: Don’t display digit–word phone numbers; use digits only.

rules.title: Foreign numbers – international format
rules.message: Write foreign numbers in international format (e.g., +1…, +44…).

rules.title: Comma after fronted adverbial clause
rules.message: Insert a comma after an initial subordinate (adverbial) clause.

rules.title: Use ‘whether’ (not ‘if’) for explicit alternatives after ask/know/wonder/decide
rules.message: Use ‘whether … or …’ (not ‘if … or …’) when presenting two alternatives after verbs like ask/know/wonder/decide.

rules.title: Clause must contain a verb
rules.message: Flag clauses/sentences that appear to have no verb (likely fragments).

rules.title: Ensure a complete sentence
rules.message: Each sentence must express a complete idea and include at least a subject and a finite verb (subject may be implied in imperatives).

rules.title: Subject–predicate clarity
rules.message: Make the subject and predicate clear; include an object or complement only when needed.

rules.title: Imperative: omit ‘you’ subject
rules.message: Prefer imperative mood with an implied ‘you’ rather than explicitly writing ‘you’ in instructions.

rules.title: Identify simple sentences
rules.message: Treat as simple only those sentences with one main clause and one complete verb.

rules.title: Compound clauses: comma with different subjects
rules.message: When two main clauses with different subjects are joined by and/or/but/so, insert a comma before the conjunction.

rules.title: Compound clauses: no comma with shared subject
rules.message: If two joined clauses share the same subject, do not repeat the subject and do not insert a comma before the conjunction.

rules.title: Complex sentence comma after fronted subordinate clause
rules.message: When a subordinate clause comes first, follow it with a comma before the main clause.

rules.title: Prefer active voice (SVO)
rules.message: Prefer simple subject–verb–object order with active verbs for clarity.

rules.title: Reserve passive voice for good reasons
rules.message: Use passive voice only when the actor is unknown, irrelevant, or must be concealed.

rules.title: Include agent in passive when useful
rules.message: If using passive and the agent adds clarity, include a ‘by …’ phrase.

rules.title: No apostrophe in generic plural modifiers
rules.message: Generic plural modifiers before a singular head noun take no apostrophe (e.g., write 'visitors book', not 'visitors’ book').

rules.title: Possessive marker on end of compound
rules.message: In hyphenated compounds used possessively, place the apostrophe at the end of the whole compound (e.g., 'commander-in-chief’s').

rules.title: Avoid phrase fragments as sentences
rules.message: Flag sentences that appear to be standalone phrases lacking a subject and finite verb.

rules.title: Comma after “Best of all” opener
rules.message: Insert a comma after the introductory adverbial 'Best of all'.

rules.title: “Because of” adverbial allowed
rules.message: ‘Because of + noun phrase’ is a valid adverbial of reason; don’t flag as an error.

rules.title: Apostrophe shows possession
rules.message: Use an apostrophe to show possession.

rules.title: Possession: singular noun
rules.message: Add ’s to singular nouns to show possession.

rules.title: Possession: plural noun ending in s
rules.message: Do not add another ’s after plural nouns ending in s.

rules.title: Possession: plural noun not ending in s
rules.message: Add ’s to plural nouns not ending in s.

rules.title: Proper names ending in s
rules.message: Proper names ending in s take ’s (e.g., James’s).

rules.title: Descriptive phrase
rules.message: Do not use an apostrophe in descriptive noun phrases (e.g., workers compensation).

rules.title: Shortened form possession
rules.message: Add ’s to shortened forms to show possession.

rules.title: Shortened form plural
rules.message: Do not use apostrophe+s to pluralise shortened forms.

rules.title: Don’t define shortened forms with possessive
rules.message: Do not put ’s after acronym when introducing it.

rules.title: Possessive pronouns
rules.message: Possessive pronouns never take an apostrophe.

rules.title: Australian place names
rules.message: Do not use apostrophes in official Australian place names (e.g., Kings Cross).

rules.title: Time expressions
rules.message: No apostrophe in plural time periods; use in singular.

rules.title: Apostrophe in contractions
rules.message: Use apostrophe for omitted letters in contractions.

rules.title: Apostrophe not for plurals
rules.message: Do not use apostrophes to pluralise nouns.

rules.title: Apostrophes for letters/digits
rules.message: Use apostrophes for clarity with single letters or digits.

rules.title: Apostrophe as sound marker
rules.message: Apostrophes can mark glottal stops or sounds in transliterations.

rules.title: Official names
rules.message: Follow official names as published, including apostrophes.

rules.title: Use brackets for non-essential info
rules.message: Use brackets only for text that can be removed without changing meaning.

rules.title: Parentheses for definitions/short forms
rules.message: Use parentheses for definitions, abbreviations, cross-references, citations, or extra detail.

rules.title: Avoid nesting parentheses
rules.message: Do not nest parentheses; if unavoidable, use square brackets inside parentheses.

rules.title: Square brackets for insertions in quotes
rules.message: Use square brackets to mark insertions, clarifications, or paraphrases in quotations.

rules.title: Use [sic] for original errors
rules.message: Show original author’s errors in quotes with [sic] in square brackets.

rules.title: Punctuation inside brackets
rules.message: Punctuate bracketed text as if outside; only use commas after closing brackets if required.

rules.title: Brackets match surrounding text style
rules.message: Format brackets in the same typeface as the surrounding text.

rules.title: Limit colon use
rules.message: Only use colons when essential; overuse creates confusion.

rules.title: Introduce examples and contrasts
rules.message: Use a colon to add detail, examples, contrasts, or a question.

rules.title: Start lists with colon
rules.message: Introduce lists with a colon; omit if the list continues the sentence.

rules.title: Lower case after colon
rules.message: Use lower case after colon unless proper noun or full-sentence question.

rules.title: Capitalise full question after colon
rules.message: Capitalise the first word of a full-sentence question introduced by a colon.

rules.title: Book/article subtitles
rules.message: Use colon before subtitles; lower case after unless proper noun.

rules.title: Introduce block quotations
rules.message: Introduce block quotations with a colon.

rules.title: Mathematical ratios
rules.message: Express ratios with a colon and no spaces after it.

rules.title: Time references
rules.message: Use a colon, not a full stop, to separate hours and minutes in times.

rules.title: Comma after introductory elements
rules.message: Place a comma after introductory words, phrases, or clauses.

rules.title: Avoid comma after very short intro
rules.message: Do not use a comma after short introductory words in very short sentences.

rules.title: Comma after numeral–numeral intro
rules.message: Use a comma after an introductory phrase ending with a numeral followed by another numeral.

rules.title: Non-essential info comma pair
rules.message: Use paired commas to isolate non-essential information within a sentence.

rules.title: Non-essential clause commas
rules.message: Place commas around non-essential clauses; omit if essential to meaning.

rules.title: Appositive comma pair
rules.message: Place commas around nouns that define the same thing they follow.

rules.title: Tag questions comma
rules.message: Use a comma before a question tag.

rules.title: ‘for example’ commas
rules.message: Use commas before and after ‘for example’ in a sentence, or after it when at the start.

rules.title: No comma after e.g./i.e.
rules.message: Do not place a comma after Latin short forms such as e.g. and i.e.

rules.title: Clauses joined by conjunction comma use
rules.message: Use a comma before a coordinating conjunction only if clauses have different subjects.

rules.title: Avoid comma splice
rules.message: Do not join two independent sentences with a comma unless also using a coordinating conjunction.

rules.title: List commas, no Oxford
rules.message: Use commas to separate list items; omit the Oxford comma unless clarity requires it.

rules.title: Oxford comma for clarity
rules.message: Use the Oxford comma only when it prevents ambiguity.

rules.title: Adjective commas (same type)
rules.message: Use commas between adjectives of the same type, not different types.

rules.title: Number grouping comma
rules.message: Insert commas in numbers with 4 or more digits instead of spaces.

rules.title: Direct speech commas
rules.message: Introduce direct speech or quoted material with a comma.

rules.title: En dash vs minus symbol
rules.message: Use the mathematical minus sign (U+2212) instead of an en dash for subtraction.

rules.title: Use phrases for spans in general content
rules.message: Prefer ‘from…to’ or ‘between…and’ instead of en dashes for spans in body text and headings.

rules.title: Don’t mix words and en dash in spans
rules.message: Never combine ‘from’ or ‘between’ with an en dash.

rules.title: En dash for financial years
rules.message: Use an unspaced en dash for financial years (4+2 digits, or 4+4 if crossing centuries).

rules.title: En dash for calendar years
rules.message: Use an unspaced en dash for calendar year spans.

rules.title: En dash for titles with date spans
rules.message: Use an en dash in publication/program titles with correct digit formatting.

rules.title: En dash for terms of office
rules.message: Use full 4-digit years on both sides of a term of office span.

rules.title: En dash for lifespans
rules.message: Use full 4-digit years on both sides of a lifespan span.

rules.title: En dash in technical spans
rules.message: En dashes are acceptable for spans in technical contexts; do not pair with ‘from’ or ‘to’.

rules.title: En dash only when space limited (time/date)
rules.message: Only use en dashes for time or date spans in headings, tables, or constrained spaces.

rules.title: Time span spacing with en dashes
rules.message: Follow spacing rules for en dashes in time spans.

rules.title: Join nouns with en dash
rules.message: Use an en dash to join coordinate nouns showing equal relationship.

rules.title: Avoid prefix + en dash
rules.message: Rewrite to avoid joining a prefix to another word with an en dash.

rules.title: Spaced en dashes for non-essential material
rules.message: Use spaced en dashes to set off non-essential information in sentences.

rules.title: Two em dashes for interruption/omission
rules.message: Use two em dashes for interrupted speech or deliberate omission.

rules.title: Use ellipsis (3 dots)
rules.message: Use exactly three dots for ellipses, not multiple full stops.

rules.title: Insert [ellipsis in original]
rules.message: If the quoted source contains an ellipsis, add '[ellipsis in original]'.

rules.title: No punctuation after ellipsis
rules.message: Do not place a full stop, comma, or semicolon directly after an ellipsis.

rules.title: Allow ? or ! after ellipsis
rules.message: A question or exclamation mark may follow an ellipsis with no space.

rules.title: Ellipsis on own line for omission
rules.message: Place ellipsis on a separate line when an entire paragraph is omitted.

rules.title: Spaces around ellipses
rules.message: Add spaces before and after ellipses in running text.

rules.title: Exception for ? and !
rules.message: Do not insert a space before ? or ! when following an ellipsis.

rules.title: Don’t change meaning with ellipsis
rules.message: Do not omit words with ellipses in a way that alters original meaning.

rules.title: No multiple exclamation marks
rules.message: Replace runs of 2+ exclamation marks with a single full stop or one exclamation (only in informal content).

rules.title: Avoid exclamation marks in government voice
rules.message: Do not use exclamation marks in formal APS content such as reports, briefings, or serious notices.

rules.title: Use sparingly in informal content
rules.message: If exclamation marks are used in promotional or social content, keep usage minimal to avoid alarm or overemphasis.

rules.title: One exclamation per sentence
rules.message: At most one exclamation mark at the end of a sentence; never stack them.

rules.title: Flag sentence-ending exclamation
rules.message: Review any sentence ending with an exclamation mark; prefer a full stop unless the tone is intentionally informal.

rules.title: Allow literal “!” in character lists
rules.message: Do not flag exclamation marks when they appear as literal symbols (e.g., lists of allowed password characters).

rules.title: Allow only specific uses
rules.message: Use forward slashes only in maths, shortened forms, URLs, dates, units, poetry, and some place names.

rules.title: No spaces around slashes
rules.message: Do not add spaces around a slash, except in dual place names or poetry.

rules.title: Units abbreviation only
rules.message: Don’t use slashes when spelling out units of measurement.

rules.title: Use en dash for financial years
rules.message: Write financial years with an en dash (2019–20), not a slash (2019/20).

rules.title: Replace slash with ‘or’ for options
rules.message: Avoid using slashes for alternatives (e.g. yes/no); write out ‘or’ instead.

rules.title: Don’t join words with slashes
rules.message: Do not use forward slashes to link words like Sydney/Brisbane; use an en dash or reword.

rules.title: Sentence ends with full stop
rules.message: End sentences with a full stop unless they are questions or exclamations.

rules.title: List final item ends with full stop
rules.message: Use a full stop at the end of lists that are sentence fragments.

rules.title: Decimal point use
rules.message: Use full stops, not commas, as decimal points.

rules.title: Subsection numbering
rules.message: Use full stops in section numbering.

rules.title: Latin shortened forms
rules.message: Use full stops in certain Latin shortened forms (e.g., etc., i.e.).

rules.title: Avoid full stop after web/email address
rules.message: Do not end a bare web or email address with a full stop.

rules.title: Exclude full stop from link text
rules.message: Place the full stop outside the hyperlink.

rules.title: No full stops in headings or captions
rules.message: Don’t use full stops in headings, stand-alone lists, captions, or page headers/footers.

rules.title: No stop after units/symbols
rules.message: Don’t use a full stop after measurement units unless it ends the sentence.

rules.title: No stop after hashtags/handles/emojis/URLs
rules.message: Do not add a full stop if a post ends with a hashtag, handle, emoji, or URL.

rules.title: SMS sentence punctuation
rules.message: In government text messages, end sentences with full stops; omit if ending with a fragment or sign off.

rules.title: Hyphenate for clarity
rules.message: Use hyphens to avoid ambiguity in meaning.

rules.title: Dictionary consistency
rules.message: Follow organisation’s preferred dictionary for hyphenation.

rules.title: No short word line breaks
rules.message: Do not break words of <6 letters, 1-syllable, or 2-syllable across lines.

rules.title: Hyphen with doubled vowels in prefixes
rules.message: Insert hyphen when prefix ends with vowel and base starts with same vowel.

rules.title: No hyphen with co-, cooperate exceptions
rules.message: Drop hyphen from common 'co' words (cooperate, coordinate).

rules.title: Hyphen to avoid double letters
rules.message: Use hyphen if prefix causes double letter ambiguity.

rules.title: Prefix + capital word
rules.message: Hyphenate when prefix precedes a capitalised word.

rules.title: Prefix + number/italics
rules.message: Hyphenate when prefix precedes numeral or italicised term.

rules.title: Suffixes normally closed
rules.message: Attach most suffixes directly to base word without hyphen.

rules.title: Numeral + fold
rules.message: Use hyphen with '-fold' after numeral.

rules.title: Always hyphenate “-odd”
rules.message: Hyphenate '-odd' forms.

rules.title: Compound adj before noun
rules.message: Hyphenate compounds used before a noun; not when after.

rules.title: Adverb + adj ending -ly not hyphenated
rules.message: Do not hyphenate '-ly' adverb + adjective.

rules.title: Clarify ambiguous compounds
rules.message: Hyphenate to resolve ambiguity where needed.

rules.title: Replace hanging hyphens
rules.message: Repeat whole words; don’t use hanging hyphens.

rules.title: Hyphenate spelled-out 21–99
rules.message: Spell-out 21–99 with hyphens.

rules.title: Hyphenate fractions
rules.message: Use hyphens in spelled-out fractions.

rules.title: Don’t hyphenate “-ing/-ed” verbs
rules.message: Don’t hyphenate participles unless exceptions apply.

rules.title: No full stops in headings, headers, captions
rules.message: Do not end headings, page headers, footers, or captions with a full stop.

rules.title: No semicolons at list ends
rules.message: Do not place a semicolon at the end of bullet list items.

rules.title: No full stops in list items (unless sentence or last item)
rules.message: Avoid full stops at the end of bullet list items unless each is a full sentence or the last item.

rules.title: No full stops in acronyms/initialisms
rules.message: Write acronyms/initialisms without full stops between letters.

rules.title: No full stop at abbreviation end
rules.message: Most abbreviations should not take a final full stop.

rules.title: Single space after sentence punctuation
rules.message: Use only one space after a sentence-ending punctuation mark.

rules.title: Capitalise first word in sentence/heading
rules.message: The first word in sentences and headings must start with a capital letter.

rules.title: No all-caps headings
rules.message: Do not use all capitals for headings (unless WCAG-justified design).

rules.title: Sentence case for titles of works
rules.message: Use sentence case + italics when citing titles of works.

rules.title: Capitals for proper nouns only
rules.message: Use initial capitals for proper nouns, not for common nouns/adjectives.

rules.title: Shortened form capitalisation
rules.message: Acronyms keep capitals; full terms follow normal noun rules.

rules.title: Capitals for official titles before names
rules.message: Use capitals only when an official title precedes a name.

rules.title: Place ? after final word
rules.message: Place question mark immediately after the final word, without space.

rules.title: Question mark placement with quotes
rules.message: Put question mark inside quotes/brackets if part of quoted/bracketed text; outside if not.

rules.title: Use ? for uncertainty
rules.message: Insert question mark to show uncertainty in dates or details.

rules.title: Direct questions end with ?
rules.message: Direct questions must end with a question mark.

rules.title: Requests framed as questions
rules.message: Requests in question form should end with a question mark.

rules.title: Indirect questions don’t end with ?
rules.message: Indirect questions must not end with a question mark.

rules.title: Commands don’t end with ?
rules.message: Instructions and commands should not end with a question mark.

rules.title: Rhetorical questions may end with !
rules.message: Rhetorical questions may end with a question mark or an exclamation mark.

rules.title: Use single quotes for direct speech
rules.message: Enclose direct speech in single quotation marks; use double quotes only for quotations within quotations.

rules.title: Quotes within quotes use doubles
rules.message: Nest double quotation marks inside single ones.

rules.title: Long quotes as block quotations
rules.message: Quotations longer than about 30 words should be formatted as block text without quotation marks.

rules.title: No quotation marks in transcripts
rules.message: Do not use quotation marks for plays, transcripts, or Q&A when the speaker is identified.

rules.title: Titles requiring quotation marks
rules.message: Use quotation marks for RuleSets, articles, essays, lectures, poems, and songs.

rules.title: Use quotes to highlight words
rules.message: Quotation marks may be used to draw attention to words or terms in special usage.

rules.title: Preserve quoted punctuation
rules.message: Keep punctuation inside the quotation if it belongs to the quoted text; otherwise place outside.

rules.title: Avoid misleading omissions
rules.message: Ellipses in quotations must not alter meaning; add context with square brackets if needed.

rules.title: Mark errors with [sic]
rules.message: Insert [sic] in square brackets after errors in quoted text to indicate original error.

rules.title: Retain non-AU spelling in quotes
rules.message: Maintain original spelling and capitalisation when quoting non-Australian English sources.

rules.title: Avoid double punctuation
rules.message: Avoid using two end punctuation marks together inside/outside quotation marks.

rules.title: Avoid semicolon to link sentences
rules.message: Prefer full stop or comma + conjunction instead of semicolon.

rules.title: Full sentences both sides of semicolon
rules.message: If a semicolon is used, both sides must be complete sentences.

rules.title: No semicolons at list item ends
rules.message: Do not end bullet or numbered list items with semicolons.

rules.title: Separate in-text references with semicolons
rules.message: Use semicolons between multiple in-text references inside parentheses.

rules.title: Use semicolons only in complex inline lists
rules.message: In inline lists, use semicolons only if items already contain commas.

rules.title: Limit use of abbreviations
rules.message: Avoid abbreviations in general/public content; use only when necessary.

rules.title: No full stop after abbreviations
rules.message: Don’t end abbreviations with a full stop, except in listed exceptions.

rules.title: Preserve capitalisation
rules.message: Use the same capitalisation as the spelt-out form.

rules.title: Don’t abbreviate sentence-initial word
rules.message: Do not abbreviate the first word in a sentence.

rules.title: Plural abbreviations take ‘s’
rules.message: Form plurals by adding s, not apostrophe-s (except ‘pp’ for pages).

rules.title: Use recognised acronyms
rules.message: Only use acronyms and initialisms that are widely recognised by users.

rules.title: Define on first use
rules.message: Spell out the full term followed by acronym/initialism in parentheses on first mention unless universally known.

rules.title: Reverse well-known forms
rules.message: For universally known acronyms, present the acronym first followed by the full term in parentheses.

rules.title: Repeat full term if needed
rules.message: Repeat the full form in long content so users don’t miss the definition.

rules.title: Government organisation forms
rules.message: Spell out government agency names first; then use generic descriptors instead of acronyms.

rules.title: Provide glossary when many acronyms
rules.message: Include a glossary when content uses many specialised acronyms and initialisms.

rules.title: No full stop endings
rules.message: Do not end acronyms and initialisms with a full stop unless at sentence end.

rules.title: Correct capitalisation
rules.message: Use capitals for most acronyms; use lowercase or initial caps only where established by convention.

rules.title: Lowercase full forms
rules.message: Use lowercase for common noun full forms of acronyms/initialisms.

rules.title: Proper nouns capitalised
rules.message: Capitalise full forms when they are proper nouns.

rules.title: No plural or possessive on first use
rules.message: Avoid plural or possessive when introducing acronyms or initialisms.

rules.title: Quote as spoken
rules.message: When quoting, reproduce acronyms/initialisms exactly; add full form in square brackets if needed.

rules.title: No full stop after single‑word contractions mid‑sentence
rules.message: Do not use a full stop after single-word contractions unless it ends the sentence.

rules.title: No apostrophe in single‑word contractions
rules.message: Do not use an apostrophe in single-word contractions (e.g., Dr, Ltd, Cth).

rules.title: Only one apostrophe in grammatical contractions
rules.message: Grammatical contractions must not contain more than one apostrophe.

rules.title: No full stop after grammatical contraction mid‑sentence
rules.message: Do not add a full stop after a grammatical contraction mid‑sentence.

rules.title: Don’t start sentences with single‑word contractions
rules.message: Write out single-word contractions at the start of a sentence (grammatical contractions are allowed).

rules.title: Use ‘no’/‘nos’ only before numerals
rules.message: Use the contraction ‘no’/‘nos’ only when immediately followed by a numeral; otherwise write ‘number’/‘numbers’.

rules.title: No full stop in ‘no’/‘nos’ before numerals
rules.message: Do not punctuate ‘no’/‘nos’ with a full stop before numerals.

rules.title: Prefer ‘Cth’ to ‘Cwlth’
rules.message: Use ‘Cth’ as the contraction for ‘Commonwealth’.

rules.title: Avoid Latin shortened forms
rules.message: Avoid Latin shortened forms; spell out in plain English.

rules.title: No full stops in acronyms/initialisms
rules.message: Do not use full stops in acronyms or initialisms (write ‘ANC’, not ‘A.N.C.’).

rules.title: Prefer English over Latin forms
rules.message: Use English words instead of Latin shortened forms (e.g., use 'for example' not 'e.g.').

rules.title: Limited contexts for Latin forms
rules.message: Only use Latin shortened forms in tables or specialist publications.

rules.title: Full stops for i.e. and e.g.
rules.message: Ensure 'i.e.' and 'e.g.' include full stops after each letter.

rules.title: No comma after e.g. or i.e.
rules.message: Do not follow 'e.g.' or 'i.e.' with a comma.

rules.title: Ban etc. in lists
rules.message: Do not use 'etc.' in lists introduced by 'for example', 'such as', or 'including'.

rules.title: Use AU past tense “dived” (not “dove”)
rules.message: Use AU English past tense “dived”, not “dove” (unless referring to the bird).

rules.title: “For all intents and purposes” (not “intensive”)
rules.message: Use the fixed phrase “for all intents and purposes”.

rules.title: Court “judgment”; general “judgement”
rules.message: Use “judgement” in general contexts; reserve “judgment” for court decisions.

rules.title: Prefer “judgment” with court collocations
rules.message: Use “judgment” (not “judgement”) for court decisions.

rules.title: “Dependent on” (adj) vs “dependant” (noun)
rules.message: Use “dependent on” for conditions; “dependant” is a person.

rules.title: “Legal counsel” (not “legal council”)
rules.message: Use “legal counsel” for a lawyer/adviser; “council” is an assembly.

rules.title: “Conscious of” (not “conscience of”)
rules.message: Use “conscious of” to mean ‘aware of’; “conscience” is moral sense.

rules.title: “Complementary colours” (not “complimentary”)
rules.message: Use “complementary colours” for matching/contrasting hues.

rules.title: “Allusion to” (not “illusion to”)
rules.message: Use “allusion to” for references; “illusion” is a false impression.

rules.title: “Elicit responses” (not “illicit responses”)
rules.message: Use “elicit” (draw out) with responses/feedback; “illicit” means unlawful.

rules.title: “Imminent” for things about to happen
rules.message: Use “imminent” (about to happen); “immanent” is ‘inherent’.

rules.title: “Have/has/had drunk” (not “have/has/had drank”)
rules.message: Use the participle “drunk” after auxiliaries.

rules.title: Flag likely “foreword/forward” confusion
rules.message: If referring to introductory book/report text, prefer “foreword”; avoid phrases like “write the forward” in that context.

rules.title: Declare one AU dictionary
rules.message: Choose either ACOD or Macquarie as the single reference and apply it consistently.

rules.title: Use current edition
rules.message: Use an up‑to‑date edition of the chosen dictionary.

rules.title: Prefer first-listed variant
rules.message: Use the dictionary’s first-listed spelling for variant entries by default.

rules.title: Record justified alternatives
rules.message: Only use an alternative spelling to meet a user need and record the decision in the style sheet.

rules.title: Australian English required
rules.message: Use Australian English spellings for government content.

rules.title: British‑aligned by default
rules.message: Australian spellings generally follow British conventions unless APS guidance specifies otherwise.

rules.title: Follow manual for set terms
rules.message: Where the Style Manual specifies spellings for terms/phrases, follow those over dictionary variants.

rules.title: Use specialist dictionaries as needed
rules.message: Use specialist dictionaries for scientific/technical terms and capture choices in the style sheet.

rules.title: Dictionary governs inflections & hyphenation
rules.message: Apply the dictionary’s guidance on inflections, derivations, hyphenation, capitals, and foreign words.

rules.title: General use: -ement forms
rules.message: Prefer ‘acknowledgement’ and ‘lodgement’; avoid US forms unless justified.

rules.title: Judgement vs judgment
rules.message: Use ‘judgement’ in general writing; use ‘judgment’ only in legal material.

rules.title: Dictionaries are descriptive
rules.message: Choose spellings that match intended meaning and audience; avoid rigid prescriptivism.

rules.title: Capitalise titles before a name
rules.message: Use initial capitals for titles immediately before a name (e.g., Professor, Vice‑Chancellor, Dr). :contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}

rules.title: Allow generic titles in lower case
rules.message: Use lower case when titles are generic (descriptive, plural, common nouns). :contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}

rules.title: Use full titles in display contexts
rules.message: In displays (speaker intros, address/signature blocks, official lists), include title/honorific, name, post‑nominals, position, organisation. :contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}

rules.title: Avoid shortened titles in body text
rules.message: Don’t shorten titles in body text (e.g., ‘Prof’); ‘Dr’ is acceptable. :contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}

rules.title: ‘Dr’ has no full stop
rules.message: Write ‘Dr’ (no period) before names. :contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}

rules.title: Titles replacing a name: caps vs generic
rules.message: Use initial capitals when an official title replaces a name; lower case for generic/abbreviated references. :contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}

rules.title: Titles after a name are lower case (body)
rules.message: In body text, titles after a name are lower case unless part of a full display title. :contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}

rules.title: Full title capitalisation (display)
rules.message: In full/display titles (e.g., signatures), capitalise role components appropriately. :contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}

rules.title: First mention format
rules.message: First mention: title + given name + family name + post‑nominals; later: title + family name. :contentReference[oaicite:23]{index=23}

rules.title: Post‑nominals: no commas
rules.message: Don’t use commas before or between post‑nominals. :contentReference[oaicite:24]{index=24}

rules.title: Post‑nominals at first mention only
rules.message: Use post‑nominals on first mention only unless listing attendees/qualifications. :contentReference[oaicite:25]{index=25}

rules.title: Place ‘Sir/Dame’ after academic title
rules.message: Place ‘Sir/Dame’ after the academic title (e.g., ‘Chancellor Dame …’). :contentReference[oaicite:26]{index=26}

rules.title: Salutations for doctors
rules.message: When no name is used, write ‘Dear Doctor’; with a name, use ‘Dear Dr Surname’. :contentReference[oaicite:27]{index=27}

rules.title: Medical titles usage
rules.message: Use ‘Doctor’/‘Dr’ for medical, dental and veterinary practitioners; surgeons may use ‘Mr/Ms’—respect preferred honorific. :contentReference[oaicite:28]{index=28}

rules.title: Capitalise ADF proper nouns
rules.pattern: \b(?:australian defence force|department of defence|royal australian navy|royal australian air force|australian army)\b
rules.message: Use capitals for formal ADF/Defence entity names.

rules.title: Capitalise short service names
rules.message: Write service names with initial capitals: Navy, Army, Air Force.

rules.title: Full name order for members
rules.message: First mention: rank + given/initials + family + post-nominals (+ RAN for Navy commissioned). Later: rank + family name.

rules.title: No commas in post-nominals
rules.message: Do not use commas before or between post-nominals.

rules.title: Post-nominals precede RAN
rules.message: For Navy commissioned officers, list post-nominals before “RAN”.

rules.title: Only Air Vice‑Marshal hyphenated
rules.message: Do not hyphenate multi-word ranks (exception: Air Vice‑Marshal).

rules.title: Retired officers format
rules.message: Use “(Retd)” after post-nominals for retired commissioned officers.

rules.title: Avoid shortened rank forms
rules.message: Write full rank names (e.g., Lieutenant, Captain, Warrant Officer).

rules.title: Rank before Sir/Dame
rules.message: Place the military rank before ‘Sir’ or ‘Dame’ in names.

rules.title: No comma in salutation
rules.message: Do not end salutations with a comma.

rules.title: No post‑nominals in salutation
rules.message: Do not include post‑nominals in salutations.

rules.title: Chaplains/MSWOs by title
rules.message: Address chaplains/MSWOs as “Dear [Title]”, not by rank or honorific.

rules.title: Service precedence order
rules.message: List services in this order: Navy, Army, Air Force.

rules.title: No commas before/between post‑nominals
rules.message: Remove commas before or between post‑nominals.

rules.title: No full stops in post‑nominals
rules.message: Remove full stops from post‑nominals (e.g. use FAHMS, not F.A.H.M.S.).

rules.title: No spaces inside post‑nominals
rules.message: Remove spaces within a single post‑nominal (e.g. use AM, not A M).

rules.title: Order post‑nominals by precedence
rules.message: Order post‑nominals: honours/awards; KC/SC/JP; degrees/diplomas; professional memberships; MP (highest honour first).

rules.title: Order titles before the name
rules.message: Place vice‑regal/ecclesiastical titles and ADF ranks first; then other titles (Dame, Sir, Dr) immediately before the name.

rules.title: Prefer KC over QC
rules.message: Use King’s Counsel (KC), not Queen’s Counsel (QC).

rules.title: Use ‘High Commissioner’ for Commonwealth states
rules.message: When the diplomat represents a Commonwealth country, use the title High Commissioner.

rules.title: Use ‘Ambassador’ for non‑Commonwealth states
rules.message: When the diplomat represents a non‑Commonwealth country, use the title Ambassador.

rules.title: Use ‘(Apostolic) Nuncio’ for the Holy See
rules.message: When the diplomat represents the Holy See, use Nuncio/Apostolic Nuncio.

rules.title: Capitalise Excellency pronouns
rules.message: Capitalise ‘His/Her Excellency’ in diplomatic forms of address.

rules.title: Capitalise diplomatic titles in formal address lines
rules.message: Capitalise the titles High Commissioner, Ambassador and Apostolic Nuncio when used as formal titles.

rules.title: Use ‘His/Her Excellency’ to address heads of mission
rules.message: Address ambassadors, high commissioners and nuncios with His/Her Excellency.

rules.title: Formal correspondence opening
rules.message: Open formal letters/emails to ambassadors, high commissioners and nuncios with “Your Excellency”.

rules.title: Formal correspondence closing
rules.message: Close formal correspondence with “Yours faithfully”.

rules.title: Informal correspondence opening
rules.message: Open informal notes with “Dear High Commissioner” or “Dear Ambassador”.

rules.title: Informal correspondence closing
rules.message: Close informal notes with “Yours sincerely”.

rules.title: Address other diplomatic/consular staff by name + appointment
rules.message: For chargés d’affaires, counsellors and consular appointees, use the person’s name and official position (not Excellency).

rules.title: Capitalise ‘Your Excellency’
rules.message: Capitalise the salutation “Your Excellency” in formal openings.

rules.title: Capitalise closings ‘Yours faithfully/sincerely’
rules.message: Capitalise “Yours faithfully” and “Yours sincerely” in closings.

rules.title: Use ‘High Commissioner’ for Commonwealth states
rules.message: When the diplomat represents a Commonwealth country, use the title High Commissioner.

rules.title: Use ‘Ambassador’ for non‑Commonwealth states
rules.message: When the diplomat represents a non‑Commonwealth country, use the title Ambassador.

rules.title: Use ‘(Apostolic) Nuncio’ for the Holy See
rules.message: When the diplomat represents the Holy See, use Nuncio/Apostolic Nuncio.

rules.title: Capitalise Excellency pronouns
rules.message: Capitalise ‘His/Her Excellency’ in diplomatic forms of address.

rules.title: Capitalise diplomatic titles in formal address lines
rules.message: Capitalise the titles High Commissioner, Ambassador and Apostolic Nuncio when used as formal titles.

rules.title: Use ‘His/Her Excellency’ to address heads of mission
rules.message: Address ambassadors, high commissioners and nuncios with His/Her Excellency.

rules.title: Formal correspondence opening
rules.message: Open formal letters/emails to ambassadors, high commissioners and nuncios with “Your Excellency”.

rules.title: Formal correspondence closing
rules.message: Close formal correspondence with “Yours faithfully”.

rules.title: Informal correspondence opening
rules.message: Open informal notes with “Dear High Commissioner” or “Dear Ambassador”.

rules.title: Informal correspondence closing
rules.message: Close informal notes with “Yours sincerely”.

rules.title: Address other diplomatic/consular staff by name + appointment
rules.message: For chargés d’affaires, counsellors and consular appointees, use the person’s name and official position (not Excellency).

rules.title: Capitalise ‘Your Excellency’
rules.message: Capitalise the salutation “Your Excellency” in formal openings.

rules.title: Capitalise closings ‘Yours faithfully/sincerely’
rules.message: Capitalise “Yours faithfully” and “Yours sincerely” in closings.

rules.title: Capitalise current PM/Treasurer titles
rules.message: Use ‘Prime Minister’/‘Treasurer’ (caps) for current holders; lower case for generic/former references.

rules.title: No full stops in ‘Hon’/‘Rt Hon’
rules.message: Write ‘Hon’ and ‘Rt Hon’ without full stops.

rules.title: Order is ‘Senator the Hon’
rules.message: Use ‘Senator the Hon …’, not ‘the Hon Senator …’.

rules.title: Don’t append ‘MP’ to Senators
rules.message: Senators must not take ‘MP’ as a post‑nominal.

rules.title: MP post‑nominal has no commas
rules.message: Do not place commas before/after ‘MP’ or between post‑nominals and ‘MP’.

rules.title: Use AU spelling ‘Honourable’
rules.message: Use ‘Honourable’ (AU spelling), not ‘Honorable’.

rules.title: Capitalise Senator/MP forms
rules.message: Use ‘Senator’ before given name; ‘MP’ after the name (after any other post‑nominals), without commas.

rules.title: Presiding officers take ‘Honourable’
rules.message: President of the Senate and Speaker of the House use ‘Honourable’.

rules.title: Ministers/parl. secretaries may use ‘Hon’ for life
rules.message: Federal ministers and parliamentary secretaries may retain ‘Hon’ for life.

rules.title: Darwin style is ‘Right Worshipful’
rules.message: Use ‘The Right Worshipful the Lord Mayor of Darwin’, not ‘Right Honourable’.

rules.title: Capital city lord mayors form
rules.message: Use ‘The Right Honourable the Lord Mayor of [City]’ for Adelaide, Brisbane, Hobart, Melbourne, Perth, Sydney (with correct name styling).

rules.title: Geelong/Newcastle/Wollongong form
rules.message: Use ‘The Right Worshipful the [Lord] Mayor of [City]’.

rules.title: Other cities ‘His/Her Worship’
rules.message: Use ‘His/Her Worship the Mayor of [City]’.

rules.title: Don’t abbreviate ‘President’ (shire)
rules.message: Write ‘President [Family name]’, not ‘Pres.’.

rules.title: No full stops in ‘Ald’/‘Cr’
rules.message: Write ‘Ald’ and ‘Cr’ without a full stop.

rules.title: Formal salutations to ministers
rules.message: Formal: ‘Dear Minister’ / ‘Yours faithfully’. Less formal: ‘My dear Minister’ / ‘Yours sincerely’.

rules.title: State/territory salutations
rules.message: Formal: ‘Dear [Title/Name]’ / ‘Yours faithfully’. Less formal: ‘Dear [Title/Name]’ / ‘Yours sincerely’.

rules.title: Premier/Chief Minister formats
rules.message: Premiers: ‘The Hon [Name] MLA/MP, Premier of [State]’; NT: ‘The Hon [Name] MLA, Chief Minister of the Northern Territory’; ACT: ‘[Title] [Name] MLA, Chief Minister of the ACT’.

rules.title: Capitalise titles of current royals
rules.message: Use capitals for titles of the reigning monarch and immediate royal family when used as titles (e.g. “His Majesty The King”, “The Queen”).

rules.title: Capitalise “The” in formal royal styles (Wales)
rules.message: In formal titles, capitalise the initial “The” (e.g. “The Prince/Princess of Wales”).

rules.title: Capitalise “The” in formal royal styles (Princess Royal)
rules.message: Use “The” (capital T) in “The Princess Royal.”

rules.title: Regnal numbers: no digits/ordinals
rules.message: Do not use Arabic numerals or ordinals after monarch/religious leader names; use roman numerals.

rules.title: Regnal numerals must be uppercase
rules.message: Write regnal roman numerals in uppercase (e.g. “III”, not “iii”).

rules.title: Non‑breaking space before regnal number
rules.message: Insert a non‑breaking space (U+00A0 or  ) between the name and regnal numeral.

rules.title: Print: narrow no‑break space before regnal number
rules.message: In print, use a narrow no‑break space (U+202F) between name and regnal numeral.

rules.title: Capitalise “Governor‑General” in formal title
rules.message: Capitalise the formal office: “Governor‑General of the Commonwealth of Australia.”

rules.title: Use hyphen in governor‑general
rules.message: Spell the office with a hyphen: “governor‑general.”

rules.title: Correct plural: governors‑general
rules.message: Use the correct plural “governors‑general,” not “governor‑generals.”

rules.title: Lowercase generic “governor‑general”
rules.message: Use lower case for the generic term “governor‑general”; plural “governors‑general.”

rules.title: Vice‑royalty correspondence openings/closings
rules.message: Formal: open “Your Excellency”; close “Yours faithfully”. Less formal: open “Dear Governor‑General”; close “Yours sincerely”.

rules.title: Address via Official Secretary
rules.message: Address correspondence for the Governor‑General to the Official Secretary at Government House, Canberra.

rules.title: Use adjectives only when essential
rules.message: Use adjectives sparingly; remove any that don’t add meaning.

rules.title: Hyphenate compound modifiers before a noun
rules.message: Hyphenate multi-word modifiers when they precede the noun (compound adjectives).

rules.title: No hyphen after ‘-ly’ adverbs
rules.message: Do not hyphenate compounds formed with -ly adverbs (e.g. ‘poorly written’, not ‘poorly-written’).

rules.title: Don’t grade “unique”
rules.message: Avoid comparative/superlative or intensifiers with ‘unique’.

rules.title: Don’t hyphenate predicate compounds
