rules.message: When the compound comes after the noun (predicate position), do not hyphenate.

rules.title: Order strings of adjectives
rules.message: Order adjectives: evaluative → descriptive → definitive (intrinsic).

rules.title: Punctuate coordinate adjectives
rules.message: Use commas or ‘and’ between adjectives of the same type; do not use commas before definitive adjectives.

rules.title: Avoid redundant adjective–noun pairs
rules.message: Remove redundant adjective–noun pairs (e.g. ‘added bonus’, ‘emergency situation’).

rules.title: Use degree forms correctly
rules.message: Use -er/-est or more/most as appropriate; handle irregulars correctly (e.g. good/better/best).

rules.title: Use adverbs sparingly
rules.message: Prefer plain verbs; remove adverbs that do not add essential meaning.

rules.title: Flag common intensifiers
rules.message: Consider removing or replacing overused intensifiers to improve clarity.

rules.title: No -er/-est on -ly adverbs
rules.message: Form comparisons of -ly adverbs with ‘more/most’, not -er/-est.

rules.title: Use adverb when modifying a verb
rules.message: When modifying a verb, use an adverb (often with more/most) rather than an adjective form (e.g., prefer ‘most quickly’ to ‘quickest’ after a verb).

rules.title: Prefer better/best over more/most well
rules.message: Use irregular forms ‘better/best’ instead of ‘more/most well’.

rules.title: Prefer earlier/earliest over more/most early
rules.message: Use ‘earlier/earliest’ rather than ‘more/most early’.

rules.title: Adverbs modify verbs/adjectives/adverbs
rules.message: Ensure adverbs modify the correct part of speech; many end in -ly but not all.

rules.title: Curb sentence‑opening discourse adverbs
rules.message: Avoid weak sentence openers that can reduce clarity; prefer direct statements.

rules.title: Don’t use “with …,” to bolt on a clause (sentence start)
rules.message: Avoid starting a sentence with “With …,” as a pseudo‑conjunction; rewrite or split the sentence.

rules.title: Don’t use “, with …” to tack on a clause (sentence end)
rules.message: Don’t append “, with …” to add a clause at the end; rewrite or split.

rules.title: Use matched correlative pairs
rules.message: Use paired conjunctions correctly (either/or, neither/nor, whether/or, both/and) and keep the elements parallel.

rules.title: Flag mismatched pairs: “either…nor” or “neither…or”
rules.message: Correct mismatched correlative pairs to either/or or neither/nor.

rules.title: Conjunctive adverbs: use sparingly
rules.message: Conjunctive adverbs link clauses but are weaker than conjunctions; prefer simpler sentences where possible.

rules.title: Coordinators join like elements
rules.message: Use and/but/or to join items of equal grammatical status (nouns, phrases, clauses).

rules.title: Subordinators need a main clause
rules.message: When using when/if/unless/until/because/since, ensure there is a main clause; dependent clauses cannot stand alone.

rules.title: Use ‘an’ before vowel-starting words
rules.message: Use ‘an’ before a vowel-starting word (unless it’s pronounced with a leading ‘y’ sound).

rules.title: Use ‘a’ before consonant-starting words
rules.message: Use ‘a’ before a consonant-starting word.

rules.title: Y‑glide u‑words take ‘a’
rules.message: Use ‘a’ (not ‘an’) before words like ‘university’, ‘universal’, ‘unique’.

rules.title: Silent‑h words take ‘an’
rules.message: Use ‘an’ (not ‘a’) before silent‑h words like ‘honour’ and ‘hour’.

rules.title: Sounded‑h words take ‘a’
rules.message: Use ‘a’ (not ‘an’) before sounded‑h words like ‘historian’ and ‘hotel’.

rules.title: Initialisms with vowel sounds take ‘an’
rules.message: Use ‘an’ before initialisms that begin with letters pronounced with an initial vowel sound (F, H, L, M, N, R, S, X).

rules.title: No apostrophes for simple plurals (paired)
rules.message: Do not use apostrophes to make simple plurals (e.g., "desk’s and chair’s").

rules.title: “Aircraft” has no plural “-s”
rules.message: Use "aircraft" for both singular and plural.

rules.title: Plural of Attorney‑General
rules.message: Use "attorneys‑general" as the plural.

rules.title: Collective noun → default singular verb
rules.message: Use a singular verb with collective nouns unless emphasising individuals (e.g., "The committee is").

rules.title: Noun‑train detector (≥3 nominalisations)
rules.message: Rewrite strings of 3+ abstract/derived nouns for clarity.

rules.title: Capitalise month names
rules.message: Capitalise month names (e.g., "June").

rules.title: Countable singulars need a determiner
rules.message: Flag likely countable singular nouns used without a determiner at clause start (e.g., "Report is ...").

rules.title: Proper nouns take capitals (general)
rules.message: Names of specific people/places/things should be capitalised; don’t over‑capitalise common nouns.

rules.title: Use “different from/to”, not “different than”
rules.message: Use 'different from' or 'different to'—not 'different than'.

rules.title: Use “discussion about”, not “discussion around” (for topic)
rules.message: For topic marking, write 'discussion about …', not 'discussion around …'.

rules.title: Use singular ‘they’
rules.message: Prefer gender‑neutral singular pronouns (they/them/their).

rules.title: Replace paired gendered forms
rules.pattern: \b(?:he or she|his or her|him or her|s\/he)\b
rules.message: Replace with singular ‘they/their/them’.

rules.title: Subject vs object case
rules.message: Use subjective case for subjects and objective case for objects.

rules.title: Coordinated subject uses ‘I’
rules.message: In subject position, use ‘and I’, not ‘and me’.

rules.title: Coordinated object uses ‘me’
rules.message: When the pronoun is an object, use me/us/them (not I/we/they).

rules.title: Reflexives only when subject = object
rules.message: Use a reflexive pronoun only if it refers to the subject.

rules.title: Don’t use reflexives as subjects
rules.message: Use a standard subject pronoun (I/you/he/… ), not a reflexive.

rules.title: Singular ‘they’ takes plural verb
rules.message: Use are/were/have with singular ‘they’.

rules.title: That vs which (essential vs non‑essential)
rules.message: Use ‘that’ for essential information; use ‘which’ with commas for non‑essential information.

rules.title: Avoid “, that” for non‑essential clauses
rules.message: Use ‘which’ (with commas) for non‑essential clauses.

rules.title: Comma after ‘which’ in asides
rules.message: When ‘which’ starts a non‑essential clause, follow it with a comma.

rules.title: Keep modifiers adjacent to what they modify
rules.message: Place adjectives/adverbs and modifying phrases next to the element they modify to avoid ambiguity.

rules.title: Place “only” next to its target
rules.message: Ensure “only” directly precedes the word or phrase it logically modifies.

rules.title: Avoid ambiguous fronted clauses with “it”
rules.message: Don’t begin with a concessive clause using “it” when the referent could be ambiguous; rewrite to make the pronoun’s referent clear.

rules.title: Rewrite to fix misplaced modifiers
rules.message: When a modifier is misplaced, rewrite the sentence to make the relationship explicit rather than relying on punctuation alone.

rules.title: Determine word type by function in context
rules.message: Classify a word’s type by its role in the sentence; do not assume a fixed class across contexts.

rules.title: Keep sentence structure aligned to meaning
rules.message: Be aware that moving modifiers can change meaning; structure sentences so intended meaning is preserved.

rules.title: Include a verb in every sentence
rules.message: Ensure each sentence contains a grammatical subject and a verb.

rules.title: I/you/we/they not with “is”
rules.message: Use are/am with I/you/we/they, not is.

rules.title: He/she/it not with “are”
rules.message: Use is with he/she/it, not are.

rules.title: I/you/we/they not with “has”
rules.message: Use have (not has) with I/you/we/they.

rules.title: He/she/it not with “have”
rules.message: Use has (not have) with he/she/it.

rules.title: “Each/Every … are/have”
rules.message: Treat each/every as singular; use is/has.

rules.title: “There is” + plural idea
rules.message: Use there are for plural or multiple quantities.

rules.title: Modal + base verb (no “to”)
rules.message: After a modal, use the base verb (no 'to').

rules.title: “Ought” takes “to”
rules.message: Use 'ought to', not bare 'ought'.

rules.title: Avoid “to going”
rules.message: Use 'to go' or 'to be going', not 'to going'.

rules.title: Intransitive event verbs take no object
rules.message: Do not attach a direct object to 'happen/occur'.

rules.title: Use “result in”, not “result to”
rules.message: Use 'result in' to show consequence.

rules.title: Choose tense for time & completion
rules.message: Select tense/aspect to show when an action happens and whether it is ongoing or finished.

rules.title: Imperative for instructions (tone aware)
rules.message: Use imperative mood for steps/commands; add politeness where needed.

rules.title: Complements after linking verbs
rules.message: With linking verbs (be, seem, become), complete meaning with a complement rather than a direct object.

rules.title: Phrasal verbs: keep required particles
rules.message: Include the required preposition/adverb; object may split verb and particle when transitive.

rules.title: Avoid long italic spans
rules.message: Avoid large blocks of italics; keep italicised runs short for readability.

rules.title: Italicise stand‑alone works
rules.message: Italicise titles of books, plays, films, podcasts, TV/radio programs, artworks; use roman for shortened/common titles.

rules.title: Do not italicise sacred texts
rules.message: Sacred texts (e.g. Bible, Koran/Qur’an) should be in roman type, not italics.

rules.title: Don’t italicise Bills
rules.message: Bills are not italicised; Acts (once enacted) are.

rules.title: Italicise Acts and case names
rules.message: Italicise full titles of Acts and legal cases; do not italicise delegated legislation.

rules.title: Set off most foreign words
rules.message: Generally italicise foreign words/phrases not absorbed into Australian English.

rules.title: Don’t italicise Latin shortened forms
rules.message: Keep Latin abbreviations (etc., i.e., e.g., cf., vs., etc.) in roman, not italics.

rules.title: Full Latin words in italics (optional)
rules.message: If you spell out the Latin source word (e.g. confer), italicise it; keep the abbreviation roman.

rules.title: Don’t italicise first‑use definitions
rules.message: For first‑use definitions of technical terms, prefer single quotation marks rather than italics.

rules.title: Use italics for scientific names
rules.message: Italicise genus, species and subspecies names; keep common names in roman.

rules.title: Italicise official vehicle names
rules.message: Italicise proper names of ships/trains/aircraft; keep the definite article and the model/brand in roman.

rules.title: Reverse italics inside italic titles
rules.message: Switch normally‑italic elements to roman when inside an italicised title (reverse italics).

rules.title: Avoid italicising First Nations words
rules.message: Do not italicise names or words from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander languages.

rules.title: Bracket note for added emphasis
rules.message: When adding italics within quotations, include “[emphasis added]”; use “[emphasis from original]” if present in source.
